ground_truth: A jogger crosses in front of him. The film cuts abruptly to Mickey's flashback of his date with Holly, beginning with a rock club performance. Three punkers--a girl with pink hair, a girl with a spiked mohawk, and a guy with Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses--watch and bop their heads to the sounds of the offscreen rock band, The 39 Steps. The camera moves to the stage, revealing a sleazy-looking rock band in the midst of their number. As the band loudly plays on, the camera moves across the spellbound audience, sitting at crowded, smoky, small tables, to reveal a stricken Mickey and a mesmerized Holly squeezed together at one of them. A nearby member of the audience swills beer from a bottle. Holly, beating time to the music and enjoying herself, takes a puff of her cigarette. She glances at Mickey impatiently. Holly turns back to the band, who are still in full swing. The camera moves down the body of the lead singer, singing into a microphone, from his longish, curly red hair, through his cut-off red shirt and sweaty torso, to his guitar. The camera moves back to Holly and the even more stricken-looking Mickey. They are crowded in with people. In the background, a waitress holds up a tray. A man drinks from a glass mug; people chatter indistinctly over the loud band. Holly glances at Mickey once again, this time unable to contain her annoyance. She opens a vial of cocaine. Holly holds a short metal straw of cocaine to her nose and sniffs it. While Mickey pleads with her, Holly puts her cocaine vial into her purse. She holds a finger against one nostril and sniffs. She then picks up her lit cigarette and continues to smoke. Mickey and Holly, almost in dark silhouette, are walking at a fast clip along the sidewalk, arguing. They pass some lighted clothing store windows; a few cars go by in the dark street. The audience at their tables watch him, some with smiles of pleasure. A man has his arm around a woman. Mickey and Holly sit at one of the tables; a candle burns in its holder on the tabletop. Holly takes a cigarette from her purse as she holds her hand to her nose, sniffing. Mickey keeps shooting glances at Holly; she can't sit still. Holly lights her cigarette, dropping her matchbook on the floor. She bends down to pick it up, then starts to fidget in her chair. She gulps her wine; she sniffs. Mickey tries to watch the offscreen Bobby Short; he crosses his arms across his chest. The film cuts back briefly to Bobby Short playing the piano. A taxi pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly walk out of the hotel through its revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: In front of him, a jogger is crossed by. Mickey's flashback of his date with Holly, beginning with a rock club performance, is cut to abruptly by the film. Three punkers--a girl with pink hair, a girl with a spiked mohawk, and a guy with Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses--are watched and their heads are bopped by to the sounds of the offscreen rock band, The 39 Steps. The stage is moved to by the camera, revealing a sleazy-looking rock band in the midst of their number. As the band loudly plays on, the spellbound audience is moved across by the camera, sitting at crowded, smoky, small tables, to reveal a stricken Mickey and a mesmerized Holly squeezed together at one of them. A bottle of beer is swilled by a nearby member of the audience. Time is beaten to the music and enjoyment is taken by Holly as she puffs on her cigarette. Mickey is glanced at impatiently by her. The band, who are still in full swing, is turned back to by Holly. The body of the lead singer, singing into a microphone, from his longish, curly red hair, through his cut-off red shirt and sweaty torso, to his guitar, is moved down by the camera. The even more stricken-looking Mickey is moved back to by the camera along with Holly. People are crowded in with them. In the background, a tray is held up by a waitress. A glass mug is drunk from by a man; indistinct chatter is made by people over the loud band. Mickey is glanced at by Holly once again, this time unable to contain her annoyance. A vial of cocaine is opened by her. A short metal straw of cocaine is held by Holly to her nose and it is sniffed. Pleas are made by Mickey with her, while her cocaine vial is put into her purse. A finger is held by her against one nostril and she sniffs. Her lit cigarette is then picked up by her and she continues to smoke. Mickey and Holly, almost in dark silhouette, are walked at a fast clip along the sidewalk, arguing. Some lighted clothing store windows are passed by them; a few cars go by in the dark street. At their tables, the audience watches him, some with smiles of pleasure. An arm is placed by a man around a woman. At one of the tables, Mickey and Holly sit; a candle burns in its holder on the tabletop. A cigarette is taken by Holly from her purse as her hand is held to her nose, sniffing. Glances are shot at Holly by Mickey; she can't sit still. Her cigarette is lit by Holly, dropping her matchbook on the floor. It is bent down to pick up by her, then fidgeting is started by her in her chair. Her wine is gulped by her; she sniffs. Offscreen Bobby Short is tried to be watched by Mickey; his arms are crossed by him across his chest. Bobby Short playing the piano is cut back to briefly by the film. From the curb, a taxi is pulled away as the hotel is walked out of by Mickey and Holly through its revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: A jogger crosses in front of him. The film jumps to Mickey’s flashback of his date with Holly, starting at a rock club. Three punkers—a pink-haired girl, a spiked-mohawk girl, and a guy with Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses—bob their heads to The 39 Steps. The camera shifts to the sleazy-looking band mid-performance, then pans across the smoky, crowded audience to Mickey and an entranced Holly, squeezed at a table. A nearby guest swigs beer. Holly, keeping time with the music, smokes and shoots Mickey an impatient glance. She turns back to the still-playing band. The camera pans down the red-haired lead singer—from his cut-off shirt and sweaty torso to his guitar—then returns to Mickey and Holly, now looking even more tense. Around them, a waitress carries a tray, a man drinks from a mug, and chatter mixes with the loud music. Holly glares at Mickey, opens a vial, and snorts cocaine through a metal straw. Mickey pleads with her. She puts the vial in her purse, sniffs with one nostril held shut, then resumes smoking. In silhouette, Mickey and Holly walk briskly along the sidewalk, arguing, passing lighted store windows as cars drive by. Back at the club, some audience members smile at the performance. A man holds a woman as Mickey and Holly sit at a table with a burning candle. Holly pulls out a cigarette, sniffing. Mickey watches her uneasily; she can’t sit still. Lighting the cigarette, she drops her matchbook, picks it up, and fidgets in her chair. She gulps wine and sniffs again. Mickey, arms crossed, tries to watch the offscreen Bobby Short. The film cuts briefly to Bobby playing piano. A taxi pulls away as Mickey and Holly exit a hotel through revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: A jogger crosses in front of him. The film cuts to Mickey's flashback of his date with Holly, starting with a rock club performance. Three punkers—a girl with pink hair, a girl with a spiked mohawk, and a guy with Stevie Wonder braids—watch and bop to The 39 Steps. The camera reveals a sleazy rock band playing loudly. It moves across the spellbound audience at crowded, smoky tables, showing a stricken Mickey and mesmerized Holly. A nearby audience member swills beer. Holly, enjoying the music, smokes and glances impatiently at Mickey. The band plays on as the camera focuses on the lead singer's appearance. Holly, annoyed, opens a vial of cocaine, sniffs it, and continues smoking. Mickey pleads with her. They walk quickly along the sidewalk, arguing, passing lighted store windows. The audience watches, some smiling. Mickey and Holly sit at a table with a candle. Holly takes a cigarette, sniffs, and fidgets. She gulps wine and sniffs again. Mickey watches the offscreen Bobby Short, arms crossed. The film briefly shows Bobby Short playing piano. A taxi pulls away as Mickey and Holly exit the hotel.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: A jogger swiftly crosses right in front of him, momentarily capturing his attention. The film then cuts abruptly to a vivid flashback of Mickey's memorable date with Holly, which begins with an energetic rock club performance. In the club, three distinct punkers stand out in the crowd: a girl with striking pink hair, another girl sporting a bold spiked mohawk, and a guy with Stevie Wonder-style braids and sunglasses. They watch intently, bopping their heads rhythmically to the vibrant sounds of the offscreen rock band, The 39 Steps. The camera smoothly transitions to the stage, revealing a sleazy-looking rock band energetically performing their number. As the band continues to play loudly, the camera pans across the captivated audience, who are seated at crowded, smoky, small tables. This movement reveals a stricken Mickey and a mesmerized Holly, squeezed together at one of these tables. Nearby, a member of the audience casually swills beer from a bottle. Holly, clearly enjoying herself, beats time to the music and takes a puff of her cigarette. She glances at Mickey with a hint of impatience. Holly then turns her attention back to the band, who are still in full swing. The camera moves down the body of the lead singer, who is passionately singing into a microphone, capturing his longish, curly red hair, his cut-off red shirt, and his sweaty torso, down to his guitar. The camera then shifts back to Holly and the even more stricken-looking Mickey, who are crowded in with other people. In the background, a waitress holds up a tray, while a man drinks from a glass mug, and people chatter indistinctly over the loud band. Holly glances at Mickey once again, this time unable to contain her growing annoyance. She opens a small vial of cocaine. Holly holds a short metal straw to her nose and sniffs the cocaine. While Mickey pleads with her, Holly nonchalantly puts her cocaine vial back into her purse. She holds a finger against one nostril and sniffs again. She then picks up her lit cigarette and continues to smoke. Mickey and Holly, almost in dark silhouette, are seen walking briskly along the sidewalk, engaged in a heated argument. They pass by some lighted clothing store windows, while a few cars drive by on the dark street. The audience at their tables watch him, some with smiles of pleasure. A man has his arm around a woman. Mickey and Holly sit at one of the tables, where a candle burns softly in its holder on the tabletop. Holly takes a cigarette from her purse, holding her hand to her nose as she sniffs. Mickey keeps shooting glances at Holly, who can't seem to sit still. Holly lights her cigarette, accidentally dropping her matchbook on the floor. She bends down to pick it up, then starts to fidget restlessly in her chair. She gulps her wine and sniffs again. Mickey tries to focus on the offscreen Bobby Short, crossing his arms across his chest in frustration. The film briefly cuts back to Bobby Short, who is playing the piano with finesse. A taxi pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly exit the hotel through its revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: A jogger, moving with swift agility, suddenly and decisively crosses directly in front of him, capturing his attention for a fleeting moment. The film then shifts abruptly to a vivid and colorful flashback of Mickey's unforgettable date with Holly, which begins with the lively, electric performance at a vibrant rock club. Inside this bustling club, three distinctively styled punkers are particularly noticeable in the crowd: one girl flaunts her strikingly vibrant pink hair, another girl showcases an audaciously bold spiked mohawk, and a guy dons Stevie Wonder-style braids, complete with dark sunglasses. They watch the performance intently, their heads bopping rhythmically to the vibrant, offscreen sounds of the rock band known as The 39 Steps. The camera then transitions smoothly to focus on the stage, revealing a sleazy-looking rock band passionately performing their energetic number. As the band continues their loud performance, the camera pans across the audience, who are engrossed and seated at small, smoky tables that are crowded and filled with chatter. This movement reveals a visibly stricken Mickey and an enraptured Holly, squeezed together at one of these tables. Nearby, a member of the audience casually swills beer from a long bottle. Holly, reveling in the lively atmosphere, beats time to the infectious music and takes a deliberate puff of her cigarette, glancing at Mickey with a subtle hint of impatience. Holly then diverts her attention back to the band, still energetically performing in full swing. The camera moves down the body of the lead singer, who is passionately singing into the microphone, capturing his longish, curly red hair, his revealing cut-off red shirt, and his sweaty torso, all the way down to his guitar. The camera then shifts back to Holly and Mickey, who appears even more stricken, crowded in with other people. In the background, a waitress balances a tray, while a man eagerly drinks from a large glass mug, and people engage in indistinct chatter over the dominating loud music. Holly glances at Mickey once again, this time unable to hide her growing annoyance. She opens a small vial of cocaine without hesitation. Holding a short metal straw to her nose, Holly sniffs the cocaine as Mickey pleads with her. Nonchalantly, Holly places her cocaine vial back into her purse, holds one finger against a nostril, and sniffs again. She then picks up her lit cigarette and continues to smoke with an air of casual defiance. Mickey and Holly, almost silhouetted by the darkness, are seen walking briskly along the sidewalk, caught in a heated and tense argument. As they pass by brightly lighted clothing store windows, a few cars drive by on the dimly lit street. The audience seated at their tables watch him, some displaying smiles of pleasure and intrigue. A man comfortably wraps his arm around a woman. Mickey and Holly sit together at one of the tables, where a candle casts a soft glow from its holder on the tabletop. Holly takes a cigarette from her purse, simultaneously sniffing as she does so. Mickey's eyes repeatedly shoot glances at Holly, who seems unable to sit still, restless and fidgety. Holly lights her cigarette but accidentally drops her matchbook onto the floor. She bends down to retrieve it, then starts to fidget restlessly in her chair, gulping her wine before sniffing once more. Mickey tries to maintain his focus on the offscreen Bobby Short, crossing his arms across his chest in visible frustration. The film momentarily cuts back to Bobby Short, who is playing the piano with notable finesse and skill. A taxi pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly make their way out through the revolving doors of the hotel.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: A jogger swiftly moves across his path, prompting the film to cut abruptly to Mickey's vivid flashback of his date with Holly, which begins with the energetic atmosphere of a rock club performance. In this scene, three punkers are engrossed in the music: a girl with vibrant pink hair, another with a striking spiked mohawk, and a guy sporting Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses, all of whom are rhythmically bopping their heads to the sounds of the offscreen rock band, The 39 Steps. The camera then shifts its focus to the stage, where a sleazy-looking rock band is in the midst of an intense performance. As the band continues to play loudly, the camera pans across the captivated audience, who are seated at crowded, smoky, small tables, eventually revealing a stricken Mickey and a mesmerized Holly squeezed together at one of these tables. Nearby, a member of the audience casually swills beer from a bottle. Holly, clearly enjoying herself, beats time to the music and takes a puff of her cigarette, then glances at Mickey with a hint of impatience. She turns her attention back to the band, who remain in full swing. The camera then moves down the body of the lead singer, capturing his longish, curly red hair, his cut-off red shirt, and his sweaty torso, before focusing on his guitar. The camera returns to Holly and the even more stricken-looking Mickey, who are tightly packed in with other people. In the background, a waitress holds up a tray, a man drinks from a glass mug, and people chatter indistinctly over the loud band. Holly glances at Mickey once more, this time unable to hide her annoyance, and opens a vial of cocaine. She holds a short metal straw to her nose and sniffs the cocaine while Mickey pleads with her. Holly then places the cocaine vial back into her purse, holds a finger against one nostril, and sniffs again before picking up her lit cigarette and continuing to smoke. The scene shifts to Mickey and Holly, now almost in dark silhouette, walking briskly along the sidewalk while arguing. They pass by lighted clothing store windows as a few cars drive by on the dark street. The audience at their tables observes them, some smiling with pleasure, while a man wraps his arm around a woman. Mickey and Holly then sit at one of the tables, where a candle flickers in its holder on the tabletop. Holly retrieves a cigarette from her purse, holding her hand to her nose and sniffing. Mickey keeps casting glances at Holly, who is unable to sit still. Meanwhile, Mickey attempts to focus on the offscreen Bobby Short, crossing his arms across his chest. The film briefly cuts back to Bobby Short playing the piano. Finally, a taxi pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly exit the hotel through its revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: A jogger crosses in front of him, triggering Mickey's flashback to his date with Holly at a rock club. The scene opens with three punkers—two girls with distinctive hairstyles and a guy with braids and sunglasses—bopping to the offscreen band, The 39 Steps. The camera reveals the band performing energetically on stage, while the audience, including a stricken Mickey and a mesmerized Holly, sits at crowded, smoky tables. Holly, enjoying the music, smokes a cigarette and glances impatiently at Mickey. As the band plays on, the camera captures the lead singer's performance before returning to Holly and Mickey, who are surrounded by the lively crowd. Holly, increasingly annoyed, opens a vial of cocaine, sniffs it, and continues smoking despite Mickey's pleas. The scene shifts to them walking briskly along the sidewalk, arguing as they pass lighted store windows and moving cars. Back at a table, Holly fidgets, lights a cigarette, and gulps her wine while Mickey watches her restlessly. The film briefly cuts to Bobby Short playing the piano before showing Mickey and Holly exiting a hotel through revolving doors as a taxi pulls away.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: A jogger crosses in front of him. The film cuts abruptly to Mickey's flashback of his date with Holly, beginning with a rock club performance, reminiscent of the lively music scene found in New York's Lower East Side during the 1980s. Three punkers--a girl with pink hair reflecting the era's bold fashion statements, a girl with a spiked mohawk popularized by the punk movement, and a guy with Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses, a nod to the legendary musician's iconic look--watch and bop their heads to the sounds of the offscreen rock band, The 39 Steps, a fictional name inspired by the classic Hitchcock film. The camera moves to the stage, revealing a sleazy-looking rock band in the midst of their number, capturing the gritty aesthetic of underground venues. As the band loudly plays on, the camera moves across the spellbound audience, sitting at crowded, smoky, small tables typical of intimate club settings, to reveal a stricken Mickey and a mesmerized Holly squeezed together at one of them. A nearby member of the audience swills beer from a bottle, a common sight in such bars. Holly, beating time to the music and enjoying herself, takes a puff of her cigarette, an act still prevalent before smoking bans in public spaces. She glances at Mickey impatiently. Holly turns back to the band, who are still in full swing, showcasing their energetic performance style. The camera moves down the body of the lead singer, singing into a microphone, from his longish, curly red hair, through his cut-off red shirt and sweaty torso, to his guitar, highlighting his rockstar persona. The camera moves back to Holly and the even more stricken-looking Mickey. They are crowded in with people, creating a sense of shared experience. In the background, a waitress holds up a tray, skillfully maneuvering through the throng. A man drinks from a glass mug; people chatter indistinctly over the loud band. Holly glances at Mickey once again, this time unable to contain her annoyance. She opens a vial of cocaine, a drug that was notoriously prevalent in the nightlife of the '80s. Holly holds a short metal straw of cocaine to her nose and sniffs it with a practiced air. While Mickey pleads with her, Holly puts her cocaine vial into her purse, a sign of the hidden vices of the time. She holds a finger against one nostril and sniffs, a technique to increase the effect. She then picks up her lit cigarette and continues to smoke. Mickey and Holly, almost in dark silhouette, are walking at a fast clip along the sidewalk, arguing. They pass some lighted clothing store windows, displaying the latest fashions; a few cars go by in the dark street, reflecting the ever-busy city life. The audience at their tables watch him, some with smiles of pleasure, possibly caught up in the lively atmosphere. A man has his arm around a woman, suggesting the camaraderie of shared enjoyment. Mickey and Holly sit at one of the tables; a candle burns in its holder on the tabletop, adding a touch of intimacy. Holly takes a cigarette from her purse as she holds her hand to her nose, sniffing, a lingering habit. Mickey keeps shooting glances at Holly; she can't sit still, perhaps affected by the drug's stimulation. Holly lights her cigarette, dropping her matchbook on the floor. She bends down to pick it up, then starts to fidget in her chair. She gulps her wine, a quick escape; she sniffs. Mickey tries to watch the offscreen Bobby Short, a renowned cabaret performer of the time, known for his elegant style; he crosses his arms across his chest, a sign of his discomfort. The film cuts back briefly to Bobby Short playing the piano, his fingers dancing over the keys with practiced grace. A taxi pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly walk out of the hotel through its revolving doors, stepping back into the city's pulse.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. Mickey and Holly almost in dark silhouette are walking at a fast clip along the sidewalk arguing. They pass some lighted clothing store windows. a few cars go by in the dark street. Holly takes a cigarette from her purse as she holds her hand to her nose sniffing. Mickey keeps shooting glances at Holly. she cannot sit still. Holly lights her cigarette dropping her matchbook on the floor. She bends down to pick it up then starts to fidget in her chair. She gulps her wine she sniffs. A taxi pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly walk out of the hotel through its revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: A squirrel crosses in front of the octopus. The film cuts abruptly to a dog's flashback of its date with a butterfly, beginning with a rock club performance. Three elephants--a girl with pink hair, a girl with a spiked mohawk, and a guy with Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses--watch and bop their heads to the sounds of the offscreen rock band, The 39 Steps. The camera moves to the stage, revealing a sleazy-looking rock band in the midst of their number. As the band loudly plays on, the camera moves across the spellbound audience, sitting at crowded, smoky, small tables, to reveal a stricken dog and a mesmerized butterfly squeezed together at one of them. A nearby member of the audience swills beer from a bottle. The butterfly, beating time to the music and enjoying itself, takes a puff of its cigarette. It glances at the dog impatiently. The butterfly turns back to the band, who are still in full swing. The camera moves down the body of the lead singer, singing into a microphone, from its longish, curly red hair, through its cut-off red shirt and sweaty torso, to its guitar. The camera moves back to the butterfly and the even more stricken-looking dog. They are crowded in with people. In the background, a waitress holds up a tray. A giraffe drinks from a glass mug; people chatter indistinctly over the loud band. The butterfly glances at the dog once again, this time unable to contain its annoyance. It opens a vial of cocaine. The butterfly holds a short metal straw of cocaine to its nose and sniffs it. While the dog pleads with it, the butterfly puts its cocaine vial into its purse. It holds a finger against one nostril and sniffs. It then picks up its lit cigarette and continues to smoke. The dog and the butterfly, almost in dark silhouette, are walking at a fast clip along the sidewalk, arguing. They pass some lighted clothing store windows; a few cars go by in the dark street. The audience at their tables watch the octopus, some with smiles of pleasure. A hamster has its arm around a squirrel. The dog and the butterfly sit at one of the tables; a candle burns in its holder on the tabletop. The butterfly takes a cigarette from its purse as it holds its hand to its nose, sniffing. The dog keeps shooting glances at the butterfly; it can't sit still. The butterfly lights its cigarette, dropping its matchbook on the floor. It bends down to pick it up, then starts to fidget in its chair. It gulps its wine; it sniffs. The dog tries to watch the offscreen Bobby Short; it crosses its arms across its chest. The film cuts back briefly to Bobby Short playing the piano. A taxi pulls away from the curb as the dog and the butterfly walk out of the hotel through its revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: A cyclist zooms past him. The film cuts abruptly to Mickey's flashback of his date with Holly, beginning with a jazz park performance. Three dancers—a girl with purple lipstick, a girl with a feathered headdress, and a guy with curly blonde hair and a necktie—watch and sway their shoulders to the sounds of the offscreen jazz ensemble, The Blue Umbrellas. The camera moves to the clearing, revealing an eccentric-looking jazz ensemble in the midst of their number. As the band softly plays on, the camera moves across the entranced audience, sitting on crowded, grassy, small blankets, to reveal a distressed Mickey and a captivated Holly squeezed together on one of them. A nearby member of the audience sips lemonade from a can. Holly, tapping her foot to the music and enjoying herself, takes a bite of her candy bar. She glances at Mickey impatiently. Holly turns back to the ensemble, who are still in full swing. The camera moves down the figure of the lead singer, singing into a harmonica, from his short, curly blue hair, through his sleeveless blue vest and damp torso, to his trumpet. The camera moves back to Holly and the even more distressed-looking Mickey. They are crowded in with people. In the background, a vendor holds up a basket. A woman drinks from a paper cup; people murmur indistinctly over the soft ensemble. Holly glances at Mickey once again, this time unable to contain her annoyance. She opens a jar of peppermints. Holly holds a short metal scoop of peppermints to her nose and sniffs it. While Mickey pleads with her, Holly puts her peppermint jar into her backpack. She holds a finger against one nostril and sniffs. She then picks up her unwrapped candy bar and continues to eat. Mickey and Holly, almost in dark silhouette, are walking at a fast clip along the pathway, arguing. They pass some illuminated bookstore windows; a few bicycles go by in the dark alley. The audience on their blankets watch him, some with smiles of pleasure. A man has his arm around a woman. Mickey and Holly sit on one of the blankets; a lantern glows in its holder on the ground. Holly takes a peppermint from her backpack as she holds her hand to her nose, sniffing. Mickey keeps shooting glances at Holly; she can't sit still. Holly lights her candy bar, dropping her cellphone on the grass. She bends down to pick it up, then starts to fidget on her blanket. She gulps her soda; she sniffs. Mickey tries to watch the offscreen Duke Ellington; he crosses his arms across his chest. The film cuts back briefly to Duke Ellington playing the saxophone. A bicycle pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly walk out of the gallery through its ornate gates.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: A jogger skips in front of him. The film transitions abruptly to Mickey's flashback of his conversation with Holly, starting with a folk club exhibition. Three punkers--a girl with pink hair, a girl with a spiked mohawk, and a guy with Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses--observe and sway their bodies to the sounds of the offscreen folk band, The 39 Steps. The camera shifts to the stage, revealing a glamorous-looking folk band in the midst of their song. As the band harmoniously sings on, the camera shifts across the captivated audience, standing at crowded, vibrant, small tables, to reveal an amazed Mickey and a spellbound Holly nestled together at one of them. A nearby member of the audience sips wine from a glass. Holly, tapping her foot to the music and enjoying herself, flips through a magazine. She winks at Mickey casually. Holly turns back to the band, who are still in full rhythm. The camera pans down the body of the lead singer, whispering into a microphone, from his short, straight black hair, through his pristine white shirt and lean torso, to his drum kit. The camera moves back to Holly and the even more astonished-looking Mickey. They are surrounded by people. In the background, a waitress raises a tray. A man sips from a glass tumbler; people whisper indistinctly over the gentle band. Holly winks at Mickey once again, this time unable to hide her indifference. She opens a packet of mints. Holly holds a short plastic straw of mints to her mouth and eats them. While Mickey converses with her, Holly places her mints packet into her purse. She holds a finger against one ear and smiles. She then picks up her unlit cigarette and twirls it. Mickey and Holly, almost in dark silhouette, are strolling at a slow pace along the sidewalk, chatting. They pass some illuminated clothing store windows; a few bicycles go by in the quiet street. The audience at their tables observe him, some with looks of curiosity. A man holds a hand of a woman. Mickey and Holly stand at one of the tables; a flower rests in its vase on the tabletop. Holly retrieves a handkerchief from her purse as she holds her hand to her ear, smiling. Mickey keeps casting glances at Holly; she can't stop smiling. Holly waves her unlit cigarette, dropping her handkerchief on the floor. She bends down to pick it up, then starts to shuffle her feet. She sips her water; she smiles. Mickey attempts to listen to the offscreen Bobby Short; he rests his hands in his lap. The film transitions briefly to Bobby Short serenading the piano. A taxi cruises away from the curb as Mickey and Holly step out of the hotel through its revolving doors.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: A squirrel hops in front of the mailbox. The painting shifts quickly to the kite's flashback of its picnic with the postcard, starting with a comedy club performance. Three magicians--a llama with rainbow fur, a kangaroo with a striped tail, and a parrot with Elvis sideburns and goggles--observe and nod their beaks to the sounds of the offscreen brass band, The 88 Cats. The lamp turns to the platform, revealing a grumpy-looking swing band in the middle of their set. As the group loudly blasts on, the lamp swoops over the hypnotized spectators, lounging at cramped, misty, tiny couches, to disclose a flustered kite and a captivated postcard crammed together on one of them. A nearby member of the spectators gulps cola from a can. The postcard, tapping time to the rhythm and savoring itself, inhales a puff of its cigar. It glances at the kite impatiently. The postcard turns back to the ensemble, who are still in full swing. The camera pans down the frame of the conductor, belting into a megaphone, from his lengthy, tangled blue hair, through his torn blue jacket and sweaty torso, to his violin. The lens returns to the postcard and the even more flustered-looking kite. They are squeezed in with creatures. In the backdrop, a gardener balances a basket. A robot sips from a glass bowl; creatures chatter indistinctly over the blaring ensemble. The postcard glances at the kite once again, this time unable to hide its irritation. It uncaps a bottle of honey. The postcard raises a tiny wooden spoon of honey to its snout and inhales it. While the kite begs with it, the postcard places its honey bottle into its satchel. It pinches a finger against one ear and inhales. It then picks up its glowing cigar and continues to puff. The kite and postcard, almost in shadowed outline, are strolling at a brisk pace along the hallway, disputing. They pass some illuminated toy store panes; a few bicycles roll by in the dim alley. The spectators at their couches observe the mailbox, some with chuckles of delight. A bear has its paw around a penguin. The kite and postcard perch at one of the couches; a lantern flickers in its holder on the tabletop. The postcard removes a cigar from its satchel as it pinches its paw to its snout, inhaling. The kite keeps darting peeks at the postcard; it can't sit relaxed. The postcard ignites its cigar, letting its matchbox tumble onto the carpet. It bends down to scoop it up, then starts to squirm in its seat. It gulps its apple juice; it inhales. The kite attempts to view the offscreen Claudia Sheep; it folds its strings over its frame. The painting shifts back briefly to Claudia Sheep strumming the violin. A bus pulls away from the curb as the kite and postcard stride out of the library through its sliding doors.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: A cyclist pedals in front of him. The film cuts abruptly to Susan's flashback of her adventure with Jack, beginning with a jazz club performance. Three skaters--a boy with green hair, a boy with a spiked mohawk, and a girl with Elton John glasses and sunglasses--observe and nod their heads to the sounds of the offscreen jazz ensemble, The 27 Giants. The camera shifts to the stage, revealing a charming-looking jazz band in the midst of their performance. As the band softly continues playing, the camera pans across the captivated audience, sitting at crowded, smoky, small tables, to reveal a pensive Susan and a fascinated Jack nestled together at one of them. A nearby member of the audience sips soda from a can. Jack, tapping his foot to the music and losing himself, takes a drag of his cigar. He looks at Susan expectantly. Jack shifts his focus back to the band, who are still in full swing. The camera pans down the body of the lead singer, crooning into a microphone, from his short, curly green hair, through his buttoned-up yellow jacket and clean torso, to his trumpet. The camera returns to Jack and the even more pensive-looking Susan. They are tucked in with people. In the background, a bartender holds up a tray. A woman takes a sip from a glass tumbler; people murmur indistinctly over the gentle band. Jack watches Susan once again, this time unable to hide his curiosity. She opens a box of mints. Jack holds a short metal spoon of sugar to her lips and tastes it. While Susan gestures towards him, Jack places his mint box into his bag. He places a finger on his lip and tastes. He then picks up his extinguished cigar and continues to chew it. Jack and Susan, almost in dark silhouette, are strolling leisurely along the sidewalk, chatting. They pass some brightly lit bookstore windows; a few bicycles go by in the dark street. The audience at their tables observe her, some with expressions of joy. A woman has her arm around a man. Jack and Susan sit at one of the tables; a candle glows in its holder on the tabletop. Susan takes a handkerchief from her bag as she holds her hand to her lips, tasting. Jack keeps casting glances at Susan; he can't sit still. Susan rekindles her cigar, dropping her notebook on the floor. She leans down to pick it up, then starts to squirm in her chair. She sips her tea; she tastes. Jack tries to listen to the offscreen Ella Fitzgerald; he places his hands on his hips. The film cuts back briefly to Ella Fitzgerald singing at the microphone. A van drives away from the curb as Jack and Susan emerge from the theater through its glass doors.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: A squirrel scampers in front of him. The film jumps abruptly to Mickey's memory of his outing with Holly, beginning with a poetry reading. Three skaters--a girl with purple earmuffs, a girl with a feathered headdress, and a guy with Benjamin Franklin glasses and a fedora--observe and tap their feet to the sounds of the offscreen jazz band, The 23 Stairs. The camera shifts to the podium, revealing a sophisticated-looking jazz band in the midst of their set. As the band softly plays on, the camera glides across the engaged spectators, lounging at plush, quiet, large couches, to reveal a tense Mickey and an entranced Holly squeezed together on one of them. A nearby member of the audience sips tea from a teacup. Holly, nodding in rhythm to the music and enjoying herself, takes a sip of her espresso. She glances at Mickey excitedly. Holly turns back to the band, who are still in full flight. The camera pans down the figure of the lead singer, humming into a megaphone, from his short, straight blue hair, through his full-sleeved green suit and dry torso, to his drumsticks. The camera returns to Holly and the even more bewildered-looking Mickey. They are nestled in with distractions. In the background, a chef raises a spatula. A woman sips from a champagne flute; people murmur clearly over the soft band. Holly glances at Mickey once again, this time unable to hide her excitement. She opens a packet of mints. Holly holds a short plastic straw of mints to her mouth and chews it. While Mickey reasons with her, Holly tucks her mint packet into her pocket. She places a hand against one cheek and chews. She then picks up her empty coffee cup and continues to sip. Mickey and Holly, almost in bright silhouette, are strolling at a slow pace along the boardwalk, debating. They pass some glowing bookshop displays; a few bicycles glide by in the quiet alley. The audience on their sofas observe him, some with expressions of curiosity. A woman has her arm around a man. Mickey and Holly lounge on one of the sofas; a lamp flickers in its stand on the tabletop. Holly takes a perfume sample from her pocket as she places her hand to her mouth, smiling. Mickey keeps darting glances at Holly; she can't relax. Holly sprays her perfume, dropping her leaflet on the carpet. She bends down to retrieve it, then begins to sway in her seat. She sips her juice; she smells. Mickey tries to listen to the offscreen Bobby Short; he uncrosses his legs. The film shifts back momentarily to Bobby Short tickling the ivories. A limousine drifts towards the sidewalk as Mickey and Holly step out of the restaurant through its sliding glass doors.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: A penguin waddles behind the iguana. The drama transitions seamlessly to Oliver's memory of his adventure with Leslie, commencing with a jazz parade spectacle. Three drummers--a boy with blue feathers, a boy with an electric mane, and a girl with Elvis sideburns and binoculars--observe and nod their beaks to the vibrations of the unseen jazz ensemble, The 76 Trombones. The spotlight shifts to the arena, uncovering a whimsical jazz ensemble in the heart of their symphony. As the ensemble softly drifts on, the spotlight pans across the enchanted congregation, standing at spacious, breezy, towering balconies, to divulge a gleeful Oliver and a captivated Leslie twirling together at one of them. A nearby participant of the congregation quaffs lemonade from a tumbler. Leslie, swaying to the rhythm and losing herself, takes a chomp of her apple. She peeks at Oliver eagerly. Leslie turns back to the ensemble, who are still in high tempo. The spotlight maneuvers down the body of the lead trumpeter, chanting into a megaphone, from his short, sleek black mane, through his full-length yellow cape and dry legs, to his saxophone. The spotlight drifts back to Leslie and the even more gleeful-looking Oliver. They are dancing with creatures. In the foreground, a chef lifts up a platter. A lady sips from a clay cup; creatures whisper clearly over the gentle ensemble. Leslie peeks at Oliver once more, this time unable to contain her excitement. She opens a jar of peppermints. Leslie holds a plastic straw of peppermint to her ear and listens. While Oliver jokes with her, Leslie puts her peppermint jar into her backpack. She holds a finger against one earpiece and listens. She then grabs her uneaten apple and continues to munch. Oliver and Leslie, almost in bright silhouette, are skipping at a brisk pace along the shoreline, laughing. They pass some illuminated candy store entrances; a herd of bicycles glides by in the bright alley. The congregation at their balconies observes her, some with grins of cheer. A cat has its tail around a bunny. Oliver and Leslie hop at one of the balconies; a torch flickers in its lantern on the banister. Leslie takes an apple from her backpack as she holds her ear to her headphones, listening. Oliver keeps taking peeks at Leslie; she can't stop hopping. Leslie munches her apple, dropping her lollipop on the sand. She stoops down to retrieve it, then begins to bounce in her hammock. She sips her juice; she listens. Oliver attempts to hear the unseen Benny Goodman; he rests his hands on his knees. The drama shifts back briefly to Benny Goodman strumming the violin. A rickshaw rolls away from the avenue as Oliver and Leslie skip out of the aquarium through its sliding gates.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Mickey experiences a flashback of his date with Holly at a rock club. Punkers and a captivated audience, including Mickey and Holly, watch The 39 Steps perform. Holly, enjoying the music, smokes and becomes impatient with Mickey. Despite his concern, she sniffs cocaine discreetly. As they walk along the sidewalk, they continue to argue, passing lit store windows. In the club, some audience members smile, and couples enjoy the music. Seated at a table, Holly lights a cigarette and fidgets, while Mickey watches her and the offscreen performer, Bobby Short. The scene cuts to Bobby playing piano, as Mickey and Holly leave the hotel, exiting through revolving doors.
